content.title: COPD Exacerbation (AECOPD)
content.summary: Acute worsening of respiratory symptoms in COPD requiring escalation of therapy
key_points: Triad: worsened dyspnea, increased sputum volume, sputum purulence
Triggers: viral infection (most common), bacterial infection, environmental
Treatment: bronchodilators, systemic steroids (5 days), ± antibiotics
Antibiotics if purulent sputum or need for mechanical ventilation
NIV reduces intubation and mortality in hypercapnic respiratory failure
Prevent future exacerbations with optimized COPD therapy

statement.text: COPD exacerbation (AECOPD) is an acute worsening of respiratory symptoms beyond normal day-to-day variation, requiring escalation of treatment. Management includes short-acting bronchodilators, systemic corticosteroids (prednisone 40mg × 5 days), and antibiotics when indicated by purulent sputum or severe exacerbation.
statement.formal: AECOPD Treatment = SABA/SAMA + Systemic steroids (5 days) + Antibiotics (if purulent sputum/severe) ± NIV (if hypercapnic failure)

explanation.intuition: An exacerbation is like a sudden storm in already damaged lungs. The already narrowed airways become more inflamed and constricted, mucus production increases, and gas exchange worsens. Quick treatment with bronchodilators and steroids calms the storm.
explanation.key_insight: NIV is the key intervention that reduces intubation and death in AECOPD with hypercapnic respiratory failure. Early application of BiPAP can prevent the need for invasive ventilation.

definitions_glossary.AECOPD: Acute exacerbation of COPD - worsening symptoms requiring therapy change
definitions_glossary.Anthonisen_criteria: Classic triad: increased dyspnea, sputum volume, sputum purulence
definitions_glossary.BiPAP: Bilevel positive airway pressure - assists ventilation non-invasively
definitions_glossary.frequent_exacerbator: ≥2 moderate or ≥1 severe (hospitalized) exacerbation per year

triggers: Viral infections (rhinovirus, influenza, RSV) - most common
Bacterial infections (H. influenzae, S. pneumoniae, M. catarrhalis, P. aeruginosa)
pathophysiology.mechanism: Trigger → airway inflammation → bronchospasm + increased mucus → worsened obstruction → V/Q mismatch → hypoxemia ± hypercapnia

workup: ABG if respiratory distress (assess for hypercapnia)

bronchodilators.SABA: Albuterol nebulizer 2.5mg or MDI 4-8 puffs q1-4h
bronchodilators.SAMA: Ipratropium nebulizer 0.5mg or MDI 4-8 puffs q4-6h

systemic_steroids.evidence: REDUCE trial showed 5-day course as effective as 14-day
systemic_steroids.IV_steroids: Methylprednisolone 40-60mg IV if unable to take PO

treatment_options.oxygen_therapy: Target SpO2 88-92% (avoid over-oxygenation → suppress hypoxic drive)

NIV.settings: BiPAP: start IPAP 10-12, EPAP 4-5; titrate to reduce work of breathing

treatment_options.intubation: If NIV fails, worsening mental status, or hemodynamic instability

definition.@value: Acute worsening of respiratory symptoms in COPD beyond normal day-to-day variation requiring escalation of therapy

learning_objectives: Apply NIV for hypercapnic respiratory failure
Identify and address modifiable exacerbation risk factors
clinical_pearls: Antibiotics only if purulent sputum or severe exacerbation
Target SpO2 88-92% - over-oxygenation can worsen hypercapnia
NIV reduces intubation by 65% - use early in hypercapnic failure
Every hospitalized exacerbation increases future exacerbation risk

sources.source: Leuppi JD, et al. Short-term vs conventional glucocorticoid therapy in AECOPD (REDUCE). JAMA 2013
